div.head: Summary Of The General News.
div.summary: News from reports dating Aug. 27-Sept. 1, 1862. Reports of movements and battles all around the country--Kentucky, Louisiana, Arkansas, Tennessee (Gen. Johnson surrenders his 700 men to Morgan's 1800 rebel fighters), Missouri too. Cumberland Gap, northern Virginia, and Pennsylvania. Also an agreement from the railroads to transport horses and grooms free one way (for the National Horse Exhibition at Williamsport).

div.head: The Nomination For Congress
div.summary: The editors provide excerpts from various local and a few distant papers--the Herald, the Bedford Inquirer, the Fulton Republican, the Juniata Sentinel, the Shippensburg News, the Carlisle Herald, the Lancaster Union, and the National Intelligencer--that all endorse the nomination of Edward McPherson (for his third term) for Congress.

div.head: The War In Kentucky. A Severe Battle. Our Line Of Battle Formed Three Times. Retreat Of Our Troops To Lexington. Gen. Nelson Wounded
div.summary: Detailed description of the battle near Richmond Kentucky between @8,500 Union solders and @17,500 Rebel soldiers, in which General Nelson was wounded, and Colonels Warner (18th Kentucky) and Topping (71st Indiana) were killed.

div.head: A Call For Sharpshooters
div.summary: A letter from H. Berdan, Colonel Commanding U. S. Sharpshooters, to the Sharpshooters in the Loyal States--stating that he has 1400 new Sharp's rifles and is in need of good riflemen to join his corps.

div.head: To Irishmen of Pennsylvania
div.summary: Colonel George Crookes notes the acceptance by Gov. Curtin of the Brian Boru's United Irish Legion of Philadelphia, and the Colonel urges Irishmen to enlist.

div.head: Address Of The Union State Central Committee To The Loyal Man of Pennsylvania
div.summary: This long speech, given on August 26th, by Cyrus P. Markle, Chairman, is a plea to all citizens to put aside all party politics during this time, and unite against the true enemy of the Republic--the Southern Confederacy of States.

div.head: Major Zagonyi's Guide; or A Heroine of the War for the Union
div.summary: A melodramatic fiction story of a woman who helps capture a band of rebel soldiers.

div.head: Union County Committee
div.summary: The list of the Union County Committee include the following people from the localities indicated: Chambersburg--George Eyster (Chairman), D. K. Wunderlich, Hugh B. Davison, Dr. A. H. Senseny, and K. S. Taylor. Antrim--Aug. Shirey. Guilford--H. S. Miller. Hamilton--Jonas Palmer. Washington--Josiah Besore. Mercersburg--John Shirts. Loudon--John S. Hassler. Welsh Run--D. B. Martin. Peters--R. P. McFarland. Lurgan--M. R. Skinner. Southampton--Thos. Fuller. Orrstown. Wm. L. Smith. St. Thomas--John Bowermaster. Quincy--Wm. Fleagle. S. Spring--Peter Shearer. Warren--Isaac Winger. Letterkenny--W. W. Britton. Jr. Green--John Ditzler. Fayetteville--John Brown. Dry Run--Jas. Ferguson. Metal--Samuel Walker. Concord--Joseph Lane. The committee is requested to meet on Sept. 6th.

div.head: The National Tax
div.summary: The editors urge people to ignore traitorous grumblings about fair taxes, and to pay their share in order to support the war effort and the Union of the states.

div.head: Deficiency Of Labor--Immigration
div.summary: Mention of Secretary Seward's response to Mr. Gamble of Cincinnati, who had expressed concern at the deficiency of labor due to the war effort, and the suggestion that an increase in immigration would solve the problem--provided that the immigrants are not required to perform military duty (which Seward points out is already the case).

div.head: General Corcoran
div.summary: Note of the return of the captured Irishman, General Corcoran, and the observation that since more than twenty regiments (more than a brigade) have been tendered to him, he should be made a Major General.

div.head: Volunteering In New Orleans
div.summary: Since the Union forces under Gen. Butler have occupied New Orleans, fifteen hundred men (some former rebels) have enrolled in the Union forces.
Mention of the National Horse Fair that will be held on Sept. 2nd-5th, in Williamsport--horses from New York, New Jersey, Maryland, Pennsylvania, and even Virginia will participate.

div.head: "Abolitionists"
div.excerpt: "An Abolitionist is any man who does not love slavery for its own sake as a divine institution;"
div.summary: The editors reprint the definition of an abolitionist, as defined by a Richmond editor--that an abolitionist is anyone who does not believe in the institute of slavery, and who does not want it to be extended throughout the world.

div.head: The Apportionment
div.summary: This article lists how many militiamen are required of each state in order to attain 300,00. The editor estimates that the number for Pennsylvania (45,321) requires one out of every fifteen of the population.

div.head: The Draft
div.summary: Note that the time for making the draft of militiamen in Pennsylvania has been extended, and the editors express the hope that it will never be needed.

div.excerpt: "The colored men of Washington city are actively engaged in forming a company for emigration to central America, where they intend forming the centre for a large colony."
div.summary: See the above transcript.

div.head: The Command of the Army in Virginia
div.summary: As of Aug. 30, the War department indicates that Gen. Burnside commands his own corps, except for some under Gen. Pope. Gen. McClellan commands a portion of the Potomac army not sent to Gen. Pope. Gen. Halleck is the General in Chief.

div.head: Despatch [sic] From General Pope. Battle At Kettle Run. The Rebels Routed. Three Hundred Killed and Wounded. Capture of their Camp and Baggage. Capture of One Thousand Prisoners. Jackson Trapped Between Pope, McDowell and Sigel
div.summary: See the above headlines for the description of movement and battle in the Manassas area.

div.head: Battle Of Bull Run No. 2. A Grand Union Victory. Enemy's Loss Over 16,000. The Rebels Driven From The Field. They Are Badly Used Up. Great Captures Made
div.summary: See the above headlines.

div.head: The Rebels Heavily Reinforced. Pope Retreats To Centreville. Franklin's Division Has Joined Him. Sumner On The March
div.summary: The reinforced rebel forces attacked Pope's forces before Gen. Sumner's and Franklin's troops could join. See the headlines for the remaining summary.

div.head: The One Hundred and Twenty-Sixth Regiment
div.summary: A description of the organization of the 126th Regiment, that indicates eight companies are comprised of men from Franklin and two companies from Juniata. Nine of the ten captains are from Franklin: John Doebler (Co. A), W. H. Davidson (Co. B), R. S. Brownson (Co. C), John H. Reed (Co. D), Wm. W. Walker (Co. E), John P. Wharton (Co. F), George S. Miles (Co. G), John H. Walker (Co. H), and A. R. Davidson (Co. J). The Drill Master is Major H. R. Hershberger, of Chambersburg. Company 'G' presented a sword, sash and belt to Second Lieutenant, H. C. Fortescue, a former resident of Chambersburg. George J. Balsely, Esq., Treasurer of Franklin Co., paid the bounty promised by the county to her enlisted men--$50 to each man.

div.head: Improvement
div.summary: Mention of the commencement of piking begun on Market Street, as arranged by the Town Council.

div.head: At Cedar Mountain
div.excerpt: "Our boys, David Newman and George Fisher, were in this battle, attached the cavalry arm of the service. Both are said to have behaved gallantly and escaped without a scratch."
div.summary: See the transcript above.

div.head: Promotions
div.excerpt: "Lieutenants T. J. Nill and John Stewart, who left this with Col. Elder's 126th regiment, have been promoted, the first to the office of Quartermaster, the other to that of Adjutant of the regiment. Both are worthy and deserving young men and we congratulate them upon their new honors."
div.summary: See the transcript above.

div.head: Chambersburg Academy
div.summary: An announcement that the Chambersburg Academy's Winter session has begun, noting that Mr. Shryock is still the head, but is assisted by J. R. Kinney, A. M. of Schenectady, N. Y.

div.head: Sudden Death
div.summary: Note of David Unger's sudden death, caused by apoplexy, which occurred Aug. 28. He was a prominent and influential man in his community, and will be missed.

div.head: On A Visit
div.summary: Note of John D. Foster, a native of Chambersburg, who learned the art preservative from Mr. Hazelet in the Transcript Office. He was working last as a compositor in Rochester N. Y., but has enlisted for three years.

div.head: Isaiah Grafton
div.summary: Note of Isaiah Grafton's death at the battle of Pea Ridge, as a member of the 37th Illinois volunteers. He was born in Orrstown, but was a citizen of Letterkenny before leaving the area--his sister and brother still reside in Letterkenny (the article does not indicate whether she has married).

div.head: Disorderly Stranger
div.excerpt: "The Constabulary as usual being somewhere else, citizen George W. Heagy was solicited to constitute himself a policeman for the occasion, and promptly delivered the individual in jail."
div.summary: Mention of a very disruptive drunk man on Main Street who, (on Aug. 27th), was hauled off to jail by George Heagy.

div.head: The Enrollment
div.summary: Note that the Deputy Marshal's assistants are almost done enrolling persons liable to military duty; most were willing, but a few men tried unsuccessfully to intimidate their way out of enlistment.

div.head: Mr. Editor
div.summary: Alex R. Shaw complains that a Rail Road Superintendent refused to give him a pass, when he had been called to attend wounded volunteers, but the same Superintendent gave passes to Surgical Med. students instead.

div.head: The Greencastle Greys
div.summary: A letter from the Pilot refers to the company of "Home Guards," and of the twenty-eight in service, the men listed above have various officer rankings.

div.head: Departure Of Surgeons
div.summary: A list of the Doctors and assistants, spared by Superintendent Lull, from this valley that were sent to Washington on Aug. 31. It was noted that Drs. Boyle, Laugeheim and Hamilton are from Chambersburg, and Drs. Smith, Hartzell, and Maclay are from Greenvillage.

div.head: Sergeant H. R. Treher
div.summary: Sergeant H. R. Treher, son of John Treher of Loudon, is part of the Fifth Ohio regiment, and fought at Cedar Mountain, where he was slightly wounded. His letter to his father indicated that his regiment has dwindled, and that a few more casualties and sickness will wipe them out.

div.head: Guilford Township Meetings
div.summary: An announcement for the Guilford Township Meetings for the purpose of raising a fund for paying bounties to volunteers, to relieve the township from draft. If a draft is found necessary, then the money will go to the families of the drafted men.

div.head: Our Saloons and Nocturnal Rows
div.summary: A complaint of the drunken rowdies disturbing the town at night--even on Sunday. The editors request that saloons be closed on Sundays and open during respectable hours, and that a constable is hired for night duty.

div.head: Aid For The Wounded Soldiers
div.summary: A request from R. R. Schneck, President of the Ladies' Soldiers Aid Society, initially made by the Surgeon General--that the supply of lint for wounded soldiers is very low, and women and children are urged to scrape up whatever lint they can and send whatever old cloth for wound dressings.

div.head: Muster Role of Company B, 126th Regiment Pennsylvania Volunteers
div.summary: The above men are from Franklin County. The rest of the company listed in the article are from Fulton.

div.head: Muster Roll of Company E, 126th Regiment Pennsylvania Volunteers
div.summary: List of men in the 126th Pennsylvania. The editors do not indicate which of the men above come from Franklin County.

div.head: Appointments
div.excerpt: "Gov. Curtin has appointed Dr. A. H. Senseny Surgeon, and D. K. Wunderlich Commissioner for Franklin County, to examine men claiming exemption from military duty."
div.summary: See the above transcript.

A. B. Wingert, Pres't., and H. E. Wertz, Sect'y., write that John Rowe and W. W. Sellers were nominated as Candidates for this Representative district at the Sept. 2nd meeting of the Representative Conferrees of Franklin and Fulton Counties. The men listed above are from Franklin County (though Sellers perhaps is from Fulton).

div.head: Muster Roll of Company H. 126th Regiment Pennsylvania Volunteers
div.summary: Only the officers and two musicians' origins are indicated. Walker, Fannettsburg; Mackey, Dry Run; Fletcher, Chambersburg; Pomeroy, Roxbury; Snider, St. Thomas; Kent, Fannettsburg; Detrich, St. Thomas; Burgess, Loudon; Gamble, Dry Run; Downey, Fannettsburg; Beam, St. Thomas; Jones, Fannettsburg; Wilhelm, Fannettsburg, Worthington, Dry Run; Croft, St. Thomas; Campbell, Dry Run; Harris, Dry Run; Harrison, Dry Run. Of the Privates listed above, their origins in Pennsylvania are unknown.

div.head: The Latest From Virginia. The Situation--Our Army in Virginia Up to Monday Morning at 10 o'clock
div.summary: Details of Burnside's retreat from Manassas, and the Union Forces of Pope, Franklin, Sedgewick and Sumner. That the railroads were in working order, and mention of the apparent rumor that Stonewall Jackson had been captured.

div.head: Homely Women
div.summary: A short article that pities homely women who rarely find other qualities to compensate for their plain looks.

div.head: Wife vs. Lady
div.summary: An argument that it is vulgar to refer to ones wife as ones "lady'--that the term "wife" is much more appropriate and refined.

div.head: S. C
div.summary: A play on South Carolina's initials--finding descriptions of the state that the initials 'S. C.' could represent (i.e. "It contains a Suffering Community." "Its leaders invent Shameless Calumnies.")

page.pageNote: Melodramatic War fiction--a pioneer man saving his family and cabin from rebels; advertisements

div.head: Married
div.summary: On Aug. 26th, Rev. Snyder married Jacob Beck to Caroline Hartman, both of Cumberland County.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On Aug. 28th, Rev. Crider married Jos. Walk to Elizabeth Barnes, all from Franklin.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On Aug. 21st, in Wilmington Pa., Agnes Carson died, wife of Hon. Carson, dec'd. She was a member of the Presbyterian Church in Mercersburg, Franklin County.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Catharine, wife of Thomas Rhea, died in her 37th year.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On Aug. 24th, in Loudon, Mary Belle, infant daughter of Lieut. Vance.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On Aug. 5th, at Spring Run, Alice daughter of William and Emily Mackey, died at the age of 1 year, 5 months and 3 days.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On Aug. 25th, in Mount Hope, Annie Secrist died at the age of 4 years, 10 months and 3 days.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On Aug. 14th, in Peters Township, after a long illness, Daniel Conrad, Sr., died at the age of 69 years and 10 days.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On Aug. 30th, near Greencastle, Isabel, daughter of Mr. John Ruthrauff, in the 8th year of her life.
